In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   After growing at around 10% per year on average for a decade until 2008, Armenia’s 
economy has been devastated by the global economic crisis. Its real gross domestic product is 
forecast to decline by more than 15% in 2009. With the crisis at least partially eroding the gains 
of past growth, sustainable growth over the medium term in Armenia will have to be predicated 
on boosting the competitiveness of the economy and attracting private sector investments. In 
the  Global  Competitiveness  Report  2007–2008  produced  by  the  World  Economic  Forum, 
Armenia was ranked 93rd out of 131 countries in the Global Competitiveness Index and 108th 
out of 127 countries in the Business Competitiveness Index.1 While Armenia has fared better in 
the World Bank's Doing Business2 rankings, moving from a global rank of 50 in 2009 to 43 in 
2010 in terms of ease of doing business, it wants to improve the quality as well as the speed of 
business  registration  to  further  attract  investments.  The  proposed  capacity  development 
technical assistance (TA) will help Armenia strengthen the State Registry Agency (SRA) in 
providing  better  services  and  increasing  access  to  information  on  Armenian  businesses. 
Appendix 1 presents the design and monitoring framework.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Rational public and private investment decisions need accurate and timely disclosure of 
information  relating  to  the  financial  condition  of  institutions.  As  a  Soviet-era  legacy,  such 
information was skewed to the needs of the state rather than to the institutions' stakeholders.4 In 
2007–2008, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) conducted a governance, institutional, and 
corruption  risk  assessment5 for  Armenia,  which  covered  (i)  public  financial  management,          
(ii) procurement, and (iii) combating corruption at the central government level. These were 
important steps in improving governance in the public sector, but their effectiveness requires 
concurrent measures in the private sector. Armenia recognizes the importance of good financial 
governance standards in improving its investment climate.6 Post-crisis, it will be even more 
important  to  restore  investments,  including  foreign  direct  investment.  From  2000  to  2008, 
Armenia’s net foreign direct investment was in the range of 7%–8% of gross domestic product, 
but it is forecast to decline to less than 5% in 2009–2010. Increasing private sector participation 
and  investments  requires  information  on  business  opportunities.  Sustaining  private  sector 
development is high on the government's reform agenda and is the main driver for sustained 
growth under the second poverty reduction strategy paper (2008–2021).  
 
3.  In line with these plans, the Government of Armenia is pursuing an ambitious plan 
towards  becoming  a  center  of  excellence  in  governance  generally,  and  in  improving  the 
business environment and reducing the cost of doing business in particular. An action plan to 
this effect has been issued by the Prime Minister.7 A major segment of this reform deals with 
increasing efficiency and simplifying the procedures in the SRA through two initiatives: (i) full

http://www.ev.am 
2  Doing Business. http://www.doingbusiness.org

and Road Transport Sectors for Armenia. Manila.

2   
automation,  so  that  the  current  system  of  manual  registration  is  computerized;  and                        
(ii) establishing a one-window operation to facilitate business start-up. In addition to the time 
spent in the SRA and organizing facilities such as utility connections, businesses apply for 
getting titles cleared from the Patents Offices and separately file to get tax numbers from the 
State Tax Service. The action plan envisages setting up 10 "business facilitation centers" to 
handle all the tasks under one roof in coordination with the relevant agencies. It needs to be 
assessed if they would need to be new entities, upgraded regional offices of the SRA, or 
outsourced operations. The Ministry of Justice and the SRA have prepared a program for 
simplification of the functions and processes of the SRA. The proposed TA is in response to the 
government's request for support to establish an online business registry as part of this program.  
 
4.  Online business registry. Armenia has a civil law tradition based on that of the former 
Soviet  Union.  It  has  various  types  of  commercial  legal  entities.  These  include  business 
partnerships  in  the  form  of  a  general  partnership  or  a  limited  partnership,  and  business 
companies in the form of limited liability companies, companies with supplementary liability, and 
joint-stock companies (open joint-stock company or closed joint-stock company). Transparent 
and efficient systems for registration of businesses are key to strong and sound governance, 
particularly in the corporate sector. The SRA is responsible for the registration of businesses or 
commercial legal entities8 (with the exception of banks and loan companies) and individual 
entrepreneurs; it consists of a central body based in Yerevan and 49 regional branches.9 As of 
2009, starting a business in Armenia takes 15 days, including 7 days for registration at the 
SRA.10 The Law on the Unified State Register defines the procedures for public access to 
information and state that the SRA has to respond to any request within 5 days. 
 
5.  In its present state, the Armenian business registration system is totally manual and is 
characterized by outdated procedures. Since local branches are not linked to the central body, a 
branch cannot deal with a request for information on a legal entity outside its jurisdiction and 
                                                 
8  “Usually the basic legal documents for all legal entities are filed with the business registry. These can include not 
only joint-stock companies, and limited liability companies but also sole proprietorships, cooperatives, farms, as 
well as nongovernment organizations. Easy access to the registry allows businesses, lawyers, and bankers to 
easily check a company’s legal form, its share capital, the authorized representatives, members of the boards of 
directors and its founders. The business registries also have copies of companies’ charters (statutes) and in most 
countries their annual financial reports.” World Bank. 2007. Armenian Business Registry. Draft Report. Washington 
DC. In Armenia, the number of such enterprises under the business registry has grown from 89,000 in 1999 to 
123,000 in 2008. As of 2008, these include 64,000 sole proprietorships, 944 open joint-stock companies, 3,198 
closed joint-stock companies, and 39,221 limited liability companies. 
9  Each branch covers a specific region and maintains its own business register. The registration information is 
forwarded to the central body (head office) and the details are entered into a national register—the Unified State 
Register. The branches maintain their own paper-based local register and head office maintains the computer-
based unified register. Submission of forms and documents are held at head office in paper format only. There are 
eight branches in Yerevan, and a staff of 149.  
10  The Law on State Registration of Legal Entities, 2001 stipulates that the SRA must register a company in 5 days. 
The 2010 Doing Business Report on Armenia (The World Bank and the International Finance Corporation. 2009. 
Doing Business 2010 Armenia. http://www.doingbusiness.org/Documents/CountryProfiles/ARM.pdf) indicates that 
it takes 6–7 days. In practice, there are 7–9 procedures involved in starting a business: (i) registering the name of 
the company at the State Patent Department through the State Registrar (2 days), (ii) procuring a written statement 
of deposited charter capital at a bank (1 day), (iii) procuring a registration card from the State Registry Office and 
filling it out (1 day), (iv) paying the registration fee at any bank (1 day), (v) registering with the State Registrar              
(7 days), (vi) registering with tax authorities and obtaining a tax identification number (2 days), (vii) obtaining a right 
at the National Police Department to order a seal for all official company transactions (1 day), (viii) ordering a seal 
(2 days), and (ix) registering with the statistical office (1 day).

3
must refer the request to head office.11 The system does contain the register information as 
prescribed by  law  and  in  line  with  standard European  Union  practices,  and  can  therefore 
become  the  foundation  for  an  effective  and  efficient  online  electronic  registry  (Armenian 
Business Registry report, footnote 8). The existing business registration processes suffer from 
all the weaknesses of a manual paper-based system, including cumbersome procedures for 
starting a business, and weak reporting. The SRA has a website which gives useful information 
on laws and legal requirements. However, it does not provide services such as downloadable 
and online forms, register searches, etc.  
 
6.  In 2003, the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) developed a 
new technological system and implemented network connectivity for the SRA and its 49 local 
branches. This initiative has not been sustained due to unreliability of the dial-up network at that 
time and the lack of experienced and trained personnel to manage and maintain the software 
once the staff initially trained left the organization. Since 2003, Armenia's e-readiness index has 
improved  from  0.37  to  0.41  as  of  2008,  mainly  because  of  improved  government  online 
presence  (web  measure)  and  slight  amelioration  of  the  telecommunication  infrastructure 
(infrastructure measure).12   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact of the TA will be an improved business climate. The outcome will be an 
efficient and transparent online business registry that will in turn meet two goals: (i) reduce the 
business registration time at the SRA from 7 days to 3 days; and (ii) improve information 
dissemination with respect to registered legal entities, which will help attract investments.13 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will support the introduction of an online business registry and will make the 
process of business registration efficient by reducing the time taken to register companies as 
well  as  improving  access  to,  and  transparency  of,  information  about  companies. 14  An 
organization  and  business  redesign  study  will  be  conducted  to seek  the  most appropriate 
technological model for the online business registry in the SRA. This study would examine the 
                                                 
11 The TA preparatory mission visited the SRA and one of its regional offices in Yerevan. While computers are 
available, only the head office has some software, and it is generally outdated. The mission was told that in the 
regional and Marze offices the computers are also old and need replacing. The paper-based data is stacked in files 
and wooden cabinets in partitioned rooms and corridors with wooden walls and floors with little fire protection. 
12  United Nations. 2008.  United Nations e-Government Survey 2008. New York. The United Nations e-Government 
Readiness Index is a composite index comprising the web measure index, the telecommunication infrastructure 
index, and the human capital index.  The web measure index is based upon a five-stage model, which builds upon 
the previous levels of sophistication of a country's online presence. As a country migrates upwards through the 
various stages, it is ranked higher in the web measure index.  The telecommunication infrastructure index is a 
composite index of five primary indices relating to a country’s infrastructure capacity as they relate to the delivery of 
e-government services.  The human capital index is a composite of the adult literacy rate and the gross enrolment 
ratio.   
13  The Law on State Registration of Entities provides, in Article 17(4), that information held in registers is available to 
the public. Presently, requests for access to such information are processed manually.  
14 For automating the SRA, any appropriate model being used in Organisation for Economic Co-operation and 
Development (OECD) member countries will be chosen for replication. This decision would be based on a study of 
the legal and business environment by experts. One such example is the Companies House in the United Kingdom 
(UK), a state-owned, public interest, nonprofit company performing the functions of the registrar of companies 
under the UK Companies Act (2005).

4   
need for legislative and other changes to operationalize SRA’s new business model. As part of 
the reforms, the government also plans to introduce an electronic one-stop business support 
facility. The TA will provide legal assistance to the Ministry of Justice to draft any required 
changes  in  laws  and  rules  for  implementing  these  reforms.  The  TA  will  also  support  any 
reorganization of business processes of the SRA that may be necessary following setting up of 
an electronic business registry.15   
 
9.  The TA will also fund procurement of equipment and software required for setting up the 
electronic business registry. This would include networked computers with fault-tolerant server 
hardware (including backup servers aimed at ensuring adequate data safeguards and disaster 
recovery procedures), broadband internet access, and facilities for scanning and converting 
existing  paper  records  into  a  computer-readable  form.  Technical  requirements  and 
specifications for the new information technology system will be drawn up by the consultant. 
 
10.  The successful implementation of this reform will be predicated on well-trained staff who 
are able to make effective use of the new technology and systems. A sizeable component in the 
TA will support training and skills upgrading of the SRA staff. The businesses and private sector 
entities, which are the potential clients of the new system, will be approached through a media 
and communication plan. Some consultative workshops will also be arranged with the private 
sector to create ownership for reform. The training and capacity building component would be a 
major  intervention  and  would  seek  to  develop  sustainable  capacity  in  the  system  through 
training of trainers. The possibility of housing future trainings in a state training center for 
continued access to trainings after TA closure will be explored with the government. 
 
11  The Government of Armenia will set up an information technology support unit in the 
SRA. It will support the transition during the TA and administer and manage the new system 
after TA closure. Under the TA, the status of telecommunications and technology infrastructure 
will be assessed to identify critical constraints that could jeopardize successful introduction of 
the online platform for business registration.  
 
C.  Other Donor Support 
12.  The government's efforts to improve the business environment and investment climate 
are being supported by the World Bank through a number of initiatives.16 Part of these initiatives 
is technical support planned to be provided to the SRA by the Doing Business Reform Unit of 
the World Bank and the International Finance Corporation (IFC).17 Under the TA there would be 
close liaison with the World Bank and IFC to ensure well-coordinated reform support. 
   
D.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000, of which (i) $500,000 equivalent will be financed 
on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  and 
administered by ADB; and (ii) $75,000 equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Other Sources). The Government of Armenia will

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The time frame for TA implementation is 24 months from January 2010 to December 
2011. 
 
15.  The  Ministry  of  Justice  will  be  the  executing  agency  while  the  SRA  will  be  the 
implementing agency for the TA. A steering committee, chaired by the deputy minister of justice, 
will be set up with representatives from appropriate public and private sector organizations 
(including the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Economy, Central Bank of Armenia, and the 
private sector) and representatives of the SRA. The steering committee will meet quarterly or 
more frequently, if required. Its terms of reference would include monitoring TA implementation 
and resolving any policy and implementation issues that may arise, reviewing consultants’ 
outputs and reports, and giving guidance as required to ensure smooth implementation of the 
TA.   
 
16.  The TA will require consultancy inputs for a total of 34 person-months (7 person-months 
of international consultant services and 27 person-months of national consultant services) on an 
intermittent basis over a period of 24 months. A consulting firm will be selected using the quality 
and cost-based selection method and based on a simplified technical proposal. Some individual 
consultants would also be hired to fast track the implementation of the TA. The consulting firm 
and the individual consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Outline terms of reference for consultants 
are in Appendix 3.  All equipment, software and services to be financed under the TA will be 
procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time).  Procurement will be through the shopping method. Limited international bidding will be 
used for procurement of items that may not be available in Armenia and whose amounts are not 
large enough to attract foreign suppliers through international competitive bidding or if there are 
only a limited number of suppliers. All items will be returned to the executing agency after 
completion of the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund, 
and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $75,000 on a grant basis, to 
the  Government  of  Armenia  for  Institutional  Modernization  to  Improve  the  Business 
Environment, and hereby reports action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Legal Expert for Online Business Registry (international, 2 person-months) 
1.  The expert will have a background in civil law and corporate governance and extensive 
experience in establishing and working with business registries. He or she will have 15 years 
relevant experience and his or her tasks include, but are not limited to,  
 
(i)  revising the Law on the Unified State Register and related regulations regarding 
information disclosure;  
(ii)  identifying and discussing with the Ministry of Justice amendments to the law and 
regulations necessary to introduce the online business registry; and 
(iii)  with the help of the international expert, finalizing the e-model for the State 
Registry Agency (SRA) and overseeing implementation of the pilot and module 
development for training of trainers. 
 
2.  Communication Strategy Expert (international, 1 person-month) 
2.  The  specialist  will  have  more  than  10  years  experience  in  public  information  and 
disclosure and significant knowledge and experience in communication needs for public and 
private sector reform. He or she will be responsible for the following tasks:  
 
(i)  developing a strategy for private sector participation with respect to reforms in 
the SRA; 
(ii)  developing ownership and obtaining feedback, holding consultations with private 
sector stakeholders, in particular representatives of the chambers of commerce 
and major Armenian business associations in the following sectors: construction, 
small  and  medium-sized  enterprises,  manufacturing,  agribusiness,  industry, 
information technology, trade, and transport, etc.; and  
(iii)  with  the  help  of  the  national  communication  experts,  developing  and 
implementing an outreach strategy through roundtables and workshops on the 
new system in the SRA, and demonstrating its use. 
 
3.  Communication Experts (national, 3 person-months)  
3.  The pool of experts will help the international expert in preparing and disseminating a 
strategy for private sector activation in e-procurement. They will have extensive experience in 
public  sector  procurement.  Details  of  the  terms  of  reference  will  be  further  reviewed  and 
finalized by the TA inception mission. 
 
4.  Legal Expert (national, 4 person-months) 
4.  The expert will have a background in law and corporate governance. He or she will 
support the international legal expert in the revision of the Law on the Unified State Register and 
related regulation. Details of the terms of reference will be further reviewed and finalized by the 
TA inception mission.

10     Appendix 3 
 
5.  Information and Communication Technology and Business Registry Expert 
(international, 2 person-months) 
5.  The expert will have sound knowledge and understanding of online business registration 
and related information technology issues. The expert will have at least 10 years experience in 
business registration. He or she will work in consultation with the legal experts and his or her 
tasks will include  
 
(i)  identifying organizational and business process reforms for the SRA necessary 
to introduce the online business registry;  
(ii)  assessing capacity of the SRA (including staff at local branches) and, with the 
help of the training and module development specialist, designing appropriate 
skills  upgrading  training;  he  or  she  will  also  agree  with  the  Government  of 
Armenia on the institutional house for training and capacity building component in 
order to ensure sustainability;  
(iii)  assessing the government's e-readiness for introduction of the online business 
registry; 
(iv)  holding  consultations  with  other  state  agencies  to  assess  the  possibility  of 
creating a one-stop online business registry;  
(v)  preparing an action plan for introducing an online business registry including            
(a) legal and regulatory framework, (b) redesigning the organizational structure 
and business processes of the SRA, and (c) assessing the government's e-
readiness  to  effectively  introduce  an  online  business  registry  and  proposing 
measures to improve it; and 
(vi)  supporting  the  implementation  of  the  action  plan  agreed  upon  with  the 
government.  
 
6.  Information and Communication Technology and Business Registry Expert 
and Team Leader (national, 12 person-months) 
6.  The expert will have good knowledge and understanding of online business registration 
and  related  information  technology  issues.  The  expert  will  have  at  least  10  years  work 
experience in business registration and management. He or she will work in consultation with 
the international information and communication technology and business registry expert, and 
his or her tasks will include 
 
(i)  developing an action plan for creating a one-stop online business registry;  
(ii)  training staff at SRA and local branches;  
(iii)  identifying information technology related bottlenecks to effective introduction of 
online business registry and propose initiatives to remove those bottlenecks; 
(iv)  ensuring  international  and  national  consultants  are  effectively  managed, 
including approving consultants' work plans and reports prior to submission to the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB); 
(v)  liaising with government counterparts to ensure the smooth implementation of 
the technical assistance (TA); and 
(vi)  liaising with ADB on all administrative and technical matters related to consultant 
performance. 
 
7.  He or she will carry on supporting the pilot and ensure that bugs and problems in the 
software and hardware are identified and removed promptly.

Appendix 3              11 
8.  He or she will continue to support the system and assist the SRA in taking it to scale 
through replication. 
 
9.  Details  of  the  terms  of  reference  will  be  further  reviewed  and  finalized  by  the  TA 
inception mission. 
  
7.  Training and Module Development Expert (international, 2 person-months) 
10.  The expert will work with the international expert on information and communication 
technology and business registry, and develop training outlines and modules to train private and 
public sector stakeholders. He or she will also develop a module for training of trainers and 
ensure that an agreed number of trainers are ready to train 300 stakeholders in an institutional 
environment in a sustainable manner. Details of the terms of reference will be further reviewed 
and finalized by the TA inception mission. 
 
8.  Trainers and Training Experts (2 national, 4 person-months each) 
11.  The experts will work with the international training expert to train the trainers and, later, 
supervise and ensure quality control of the trainings delivered by the trainers. Details of the 
terms of reference will be further reviewed and finalized by the TA inception mission.
